I am using MSVC 2015 and PGO for my compiles. I have the latest Vulkan SDK installed as well. I have never been able to fully compile with Vulkan enabled.

Issue: Enable PRINTF_FORMAT in clang builds on Windows
Issue description:
midi_manager_win.cc contains this code:

void set_index(size_t index) {
index_ = index;
// TODO(toyoshim): Use hashed ID.
info_.id = base::StringPrintf("%s-%d", type_.c_str(), index_);
}

This is incorrect because index_ is a size_t so there is a size mismatch on 64-bit builds. This would previously have been noticed by the VC++ /analyze build but this is temporarily out of commission due to the switch to clang-as-default and is long-term out of commission because clang is taking over.

One might expect clang-l to detect this problem but it does not because PRINTF_FORMAT is only usefully defined in GCC builds. Once PRINTF_FORMAT is usefully defined for __clang__ builds this error is caught.

Unfortunately, in addition to this medium-value warning (and other high-value mismatch warnings) PRINTF_FORMAT catches many low-value warnings, for DWORD/SystemErrorCode versus unsigned long mismatches. These warnings are low value because the size and sign match. Here is some sample output:

> ninja -C out\release_64 obj/media/midi/midi/midi_manager_win.obj
ninja: Entering directory `out\release_64'
[283 processes, 342/952 @ 72.6/s : 4.709s ] CXX obj/base/base/native_library_win.obj
C:\src\chromium3\src\base\native_library_win.cc(150,29): warning: format specifies type 'unsigned int' but the argument has type 'DWORD' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Wformat]
return StringPrintf("%u", code);
~~ ^~~~
%lu
1 warning generated.
[41 processes, 898/952 @ 77.3/s : 11.624s ] CXX obj/base/base/logging.obj
C:\src\chromium3\src\base\logging.cc(875,39): warning: format specifies type 'unsigned int' but the argument has type 'logging::SystemErrorCode' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Wformat]
base::StringPrintf(" (0x%X)", error_code);
~~ ^~~~~~~~~~
%lX
C:\src\chromium3\src\base\logging.cc(878,29): warning: format specifies type 'unsigned int' but the argument has type 'DWORD' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Wformat]
GetLastError(), error_code);
^~~~~~~~~~~~~~
C:\src\chromium3\src\base\logging.cc(878,45): warning: format specifies type 'unsigned int' but the argument has type 'logging::SystemErrorCode' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Wformat]
GetLastError(), error_code);
^~~~~~~~~~
3 warnings generated.
[1 processes, 952/952 @ 34.4/s : 27.685s ] CXX obj/media/midi/midi/midi_manager_win.obj
C:\src\chromium3\src\media\midi\midi_manager_win.cc(292,59): warning: format specifies type 'int' but the argument has type 'size_t' (aka 'unsigned long long') [-Wformat]
info_.id = base::StringPrintf("%s-%d", type_.c_str(), index_);
~~ ^~~~~~
%zu
1 warning generated.



We could fix all of the places where DWORD is printed with %X instead of %lX but this adds no value. It would potentially be much better to allow modifying the clang-cl PRINTF_FORMAT warning so that it ignores these distinctions without any meaning, where the sign and size match.

I will land a fix for the midi_manager_win.cc mismatch.

Issue: replace package_build / extract_build with upload/download of lists of isolate tasks
Issue description:
Now that almost everything is being run under swarming, we should get rid of the (mostly) redundant package_build / extract_build steps on the waterfall builders that have builder/tester splits, and instead just upload a list of swarming tasks to run (isolate hashes + command lines + metadata for steps) and download them on the testers.

This is currently done and working on the internal ios bots, so porting this over should be conceptually straightforward.

In order for that to be possible, we need to make sure that in fact *all* of the desired tests are swarmed. Most notable, we can't do this on bots that run layout tests until they are swarmed :(.

Any volunteers to work on this?

Issue: BackgroundFetchContext has redundant URLRequestContextGetter
Issue description:
There is a scoped_refptr<URLRequestContextGetter> in BackgroundFetchContext that is never used after assignment but is there to prevent a crash:

components_unittests --gtest_filter=ContentLoFiUIServiceTest.*

This crash occurs because the test uses TestBrowserContext and this:
SetThreadBundleOptions(content::TestBrowserThreadBundle::REAL_IO_THREAD);

This seems to cause the URLRequestContextGetter to get destroyed on the IO thread where previous it was destroyed on the UI thread because BackgroundFetchDelegateProxy::Core gets destroyed on the UI thread via a posted task, which thus happens after the BrowserContext is destroyed.

The problem with TestBrowserContext appears to be that it uses TestURLRequestContextGetter that uses a NullTaskRunner which claims to be able to run on any thread, which means the URLRequestContextGetter actually gets destroyed on any thread.

https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/content/public/test/test_browser_context.cc?type=cs&sq=package:chromium&l=24

Issue: Clean windows build requires multiple "rebaselinings"

Machine is running Win10 Pro

DEPOT_TOOLS_WIN_TOOLCHAIN=0 [env var]
WindowsSDKVersion=10.0.15063.0\ [env var]
VS2015 and VS2017 installed

>gn args win.debug
[accept the empty args.gn file]

>ninja -C win.debug
[lots of output, including three requests to rebaseline]

After completing the rebaseline, the code did compile. [There was a separate bug with precompiled headers, which is in issue 763431]

Issue: CacheStorage: Usage reporting is sometimes wrong when caches are reopened
Issue description:
Chrome Version: 
OS: all

What steps will reproduce the problem?
(1) Unzip, run both python servers
(2) Open localhost:8084/page.html
(3) Press the new "Random Fetch (many) with 302 and new response" button once.
(4) Open DevTools, switch to the memory tab, and click the trash can icon to do a GC.
(5) Press the "Random Fetch with 302 and new response" button once.

What is the expected result?
Cache storage should grow slowly

The included localhost:8084/page2.html and its sw2.js have a workaround (using only one instance of the open cache) that appear to prevent this behavior.

What happens instead?
Cache Storage use will jump from 136 MB to 273 MB.


Please use labels and text to provide additional information.


For graphics-related bugs, please copy/paste the contents of the about:gpu
page at the end of this report.

Issue: Add support for ${applicationId} for merged manifests
Issue description:

AndroidManifest.xml:20: Tag <provider> attribute authorities has invalid character '$'.

Issue: CORS integration with Background Fetch
Issue description:
Fetches may originate from other origins to support CDNs, but we must not allow access to content that otherwise wouldnt be accessible.

We currently block every kind of background fetch request that needs CORS preflight. Why? We use DownloadManager to download items and CORS preflight code is in blink currently, which DownloadManager shouldn't talk to. (because that would require us to spin up a renderer process and that's expensive).

The move of CORS preflight logic to network service should be done by Q3, shipping will take longer but we can start building on it then.
This bug is a tracker for that work. Once we do have CORS preflight support, we can stop blocking all background fetches that need it.

Relevant docs:
CORS Support in Network Service:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JNmUcvbw2UcjfdI2uyUpveHXCbae-DQ1n8d_sVs5fLg/edit?usp=sharing

Out-of-Blink Fetch/CORS: 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mIk2or1y8nXHSQXQ6mJLGp3gLrtImONIuYhHtx1zInM/edit?usp=sharing

Issue: Separate MachineLevelUserCloudPolicy logic from ChromeBrowserPolicyConnector.
Issue description: As the code of MachineLevelUserCloudPolicy become more and more complicated. It worth to refactor the code to move the cloud policy logic into its individual class.

Issue: AR Hit tests rays are inverted vertically in screen space.
Issue description:
When using the WebXR requestHitTest feature rays passed from taps on the screen appear to become inverted in screen-space Y, so that tapping near the top of the screen actually performs a hit test near the bottom. X is well aligned, and ray casts from the center of the screen always work as intended. See linked video for a better sense of what's happening.

https://photos.app.goo.gl/qxSyuaey6LaYMUAE2

Issue: ScheduleDownload shouldn't resume paused jobs
Issue description:
This is a recently introduced regression.

Repro steps:
Start a fetch containing multiple downloads. Pause it through the UI.

Expected behavior: The fetch remains paused until we hit Resume.
Observed behavior: The fetch auto-resumes.

I think it's a bug in our ScheduleDownload logic, where we schedule one whenever there are fewer than max_concurrent_downloads active downloads.
Since we are pausing all downloads correctly in our PauseDownload() logic, we should simply check if a download has been paused when scheduling one.

In the future, we might need to add reason_for_pause, if we want to support auto-resumes on wifi connectivity.

Issue: Window state leaking from one page to another.
Issue description:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/67.0.3396.99 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Refresh document (without devtools open) until white page appears
2. Open console
3. See log that a property set in the previous window persists

What is the expected behavior?
The AMP runtime sets the window['__AMP_BODY_VISIBLE'] when it executes. This test file logs this property before any other js code has ran. This property should not be set on new pages.

What went wrong?
This property that was set on one page carries over to the next. Even though this test case is exposed by refreshing, it can also happen from page to page navigation.

This was originally reported to us by tasty.co and if you click around a few times on their site you will see the same behavior.

Did this work before? N/A 

Does this work in other browsers? Yes

Chrome version: 67.0.3396.99 Channel: n/a
OS Version: OS X 10.13.6
Flash Version: 

You may contact ccordry@ for more details.

Issue: Rust keywords getting flagged by spellchecker
Issue description: Example: https://fuchsia-review.googlesource.com/c/garnet/+/175776

Issue: Chrome's web accessibility support causes massive performance issues
Issue description:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/68.0.3440.106 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
I work on Figma, a browser-based interface design tool. We were recently made aware of a severe Windows-specific performance issue. Here's the repro:

1. Sign in to Figma (signing up is free)
2. Create a new document
3. Draw a rectangle
4. Drag a selection box on and off the rectangle repeatedly

What is the expected behavior?
The performance of the application should be around at least 30fps at all times.

What went wrong?
After a few seconds of doing this, the pause that happens after the UI updates due to selection/deselection of the rectangle can reach up to over 1000ms. Users have reported that for longer sessions and larger documents the pauses can be over 4000ms (I have chrome://tracing recordings from them to prove it). Attached is a Developer Tools profile and a chrome://tracing recording of it happening for me.

The issue completely disappears if you uncheck "Web accessibility" on chrome://accessibility. Another thing to point out is chrome://tracing shows all of the time being spent in "RenderAccessibilityImpl::SendPendingAccessibilityEvents".

Did this work before? N/A 

Does this work in other browsers? Yes

Chrome version: 68.0.3440.106 Channel: stable
OS Version: Windows 10
Flash Version:

Issue: cs.chromium.org does not search Java .srcjars
Issue description:
It's pretty reasonable that codesearch doesn't search within .srcjar files, and I think it'd be pretty easy to fix: Just extract the .srcjar into //out/Debug/gen somewhere.

We should do the same for annotation processor output.

Issue: Remove [Custom] extended attribute for MessageEvent.data
Issue description:
According to Yuki's comment[1], we might remove [Custom] extended attribute for MessageEvent.data. [Custom] is meant for the case that the bindings code generator doesn't meet the requirements of Web APIs, so that you can write your own bindings. Unless you really need, we SHOULD NOT use it.

[1] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1226774/4/third_party/blink/renderer/modules/payments/payment_method_change_event.h#45

Issue: Build Recipes Tester should test without patch, retry summary code paths
Issue description:
Currently, the Build Recipes Tester doesn't test all of the code paths in the chromium_trybot recipe. Specifically, it doesn't do much with patches, and their deapplication.

Right now, it runs with no patch. If any test fails (often due to flake), the led task throws an exception because of a failed assertion. This does potentially lead to more flake than necessary, since the build fails before it can run the tests without the patch.

It's unclear what patch, if any, the build should run with. Potentially we should just give it a no-op patch? I don't know if it'd make sense to do that, and I'm a bit worried about relying on a particular CL always being around.

Thoughts?

Issue: CSS Animations: new names for steps() keywords
Issue description:
https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/1680
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-easing/#step-timing-functions
<step-timing-function> = step-start | step-end | steps(<integer>[, <step-position>]?)
<step-position> = jump-start | jump-end | jump-none | jump-both | start | end

The jump-* names are new from the CSS Working Group's Berlin F2F in April 2018.

Issue: git cl format fails on repos not associated with Gerrit or Rietveld.
Issue description:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/70.0.3538.110 Chrome/70.0.3538.110 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. In a subdirectory containing a private repository (not managed by Gerrit or Rietveld), run `git cl format`
2. Get an AssertionError similar to:

src/third_party/depot_tools/git_cl.py", line 1164, in _load_codereview_impl
assert codereview in _CODEREVIEW_IMPLEMENTATIONS

What is the expected behavior?
Code is formatted.

What went wrong?
Commit a185e2e3c83d805d3306a3f1fe9258ae2e75f231 removed the Rietveld code review
implementation, albeit hasn't expunged all references to Rietveld. This leads
to an assertion error when running |git cl format| on a non-Gerrit change.
There appears to have been a recent attempt to articulate this error better in
a185e2e3c83d805d3306a3f1fe9258ae2e75f231, albeit not fix the underlying issue.
This change addresses the immediate issue by defaulting the code review
implementation to Gerrit rather than Reitveld.

Links to Mentioned Commits:

* https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git/+/a185e2e3c83d805d3306a3f1fe9258ae2e75f231%5E%21/
* https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git/+/d87b09662ee8a8b50b2dd36630e9a9c4df562d1c%5E%21/#F0

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 70.0.3538.110 Channel: n/a
OS Version: 
Flash Version: 

I'll post a CL shortly.

Issue: cancelAnimationFrame doesn't behave according to the spec
Issue description:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/71.0.3578.98 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
Execute this code snippet in the console:

var a = function(){console.log('foo');}, b = null;
requestAnimationFrame(function() { cancelAnimationFrame(b); }); 
b = requestAnimationFrame(function () { a(); });

What is the expected behavior?
'foo' should be logged.

What went wrong?
'foo' is not logged to the console

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 71.0.3578.98 Channel: stable
OS Version: 10.0
Flash Version: 

Well, to be honest, I do not think chromium has a bug with this API. It works as I would expect. Problem is with firefox, but when I reported problem to them, I was told FF behaves according to the specification (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/imagebitmap-and-animations.html#run-the-animation-frame-callbacks) and every other browser is not. So this ticket is meant to start a discussion and sync understanding of the specification.

Ideal result would be if chromium developers could convince firefox developers that their cancelAnimationFrame doesn't work properly.

Ticket on bugzilla: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1509466

Issue: Force dark mode: Should not invert if page already has a dark background
Issue description:
This is a companion to bug 925935 (Implement supported-color-schemes meta tag).

If a page does *not* natively support a meta tag, but an inverted-colors mode is on (currently "high contrast" in the code, but possibly exposed to users as "force dark mode"), we don't want to invert colors if the page already has a black background.

Specifically, run Chrome with --blink-settings="highContrastMode=3" and then visit a site like netflix.com or vinesauce.com. We should not invert those pages since they already have a dark background.

I explored whether checking just the background color of the page actually works in practice here:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gTVpHzBLeGEGXXix-Is6bGbrsY1eaYcQiJEL2xDiDb8/edit

Issue: compute_interfaces_info_individual.py appears to be able to infinite loop
Issue description:
I had patched in https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1531153 into my local ToT build, which included the following (apparently incorrect) .idl edit:

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1531153/11/third_party/blink/renderer/modules/csspaint/paint_worklet_global_scope.idl#17
callback PaintCallback = void (PaintRenderingContext2D renderingContext, PaintSize paintSize, const StylePropertyMapReadOnly styleMap, sequence<CSSStyleValue> inputArguments);

(The 'const' was added in the CL)

After patching in the CL, I fired off a build and... it hung. No output, just wouldn't move forward. After digging, I found that the following command was spinning at 100% CPU:

../../third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/scripts/compute_interfaces_info_individual.py --cache-directory gen/third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/scripts --idl-files-list __third_party_blink_renderer_bindings_modules_interfaces_info_individual_modules___build_toolchain_linux_clang_x64__rule.rsp --interfaces-info-file gen/third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/modules/InterfacesInfoOverallIndividual.pickle --component-info-file gen/third_party/blink/renderer/bindings/modules/ComponentInfoModules.pickle

I killed the build and ran the command locally from my build directory, and it spat out an infinite about of:

../../third_party/blink/renderer/modules/csspaint/paint_worklet_global_scope.idl(17) : error: Unexpected keyword "const" after ",".
... repeating over and over again


This probably shouldn't hang if an idl file has a syntax error.

Issue: link.exe says unit_tests.exe has a duplicate resource, lld-link doesn't complain
Issue description:
While testing a CFG process creation performance issue I tried building unit_tests.exe with link.exe and it failed:

FAILED: unit_tests.exe unit_tests.exe.pdb
c:/src/depot_tools/win_tools-2_7_6_bin/python/bin/python.exe ../../build/toolchain/win/tool_wrapper.py link-wrapper environment.x86 False link.exe /nologo /OUT:./unit_tests.exe /PDB:./unit_tests.exe.pdb @./unit_tests.exe.rsp
CVTRES : fatal error CVT1100: duplicate resource. type:STRING, name:101, language:0x0409

LINK : fatal error LNK1123: failure during conversion to COFF: file invalid or corrupt

In addition to preventing A/B testing this also probably means that we have a Chromium bug that we were not previously aware of. My gn args are:

use_lld = false
is_component_build = false
is_debug = false
target_cpu = "x86"
enable_nacl = false
use_allocator_shim = false
symbol_level = 1
use_goma = true
msvc_use_absolute_paths = true

Most of these are probably irrelevant - perhaps just the first three are needed, although symbol_level=1 helps with link times.

Ideally lld-link would also complain about this, perhaps giving enough information to let us find the underlying issue.

Issue: UKM for Periodic Background Sync
Issue description: Tracking the addition of logic to collect UKM data for Periodic Background Sync.

Issue: Wait for primary profile policy ProxyPolicyProvider-forwarded policy-derived prefs to be reflected in local_state before continuing primary profile init
Issue description:
Profile initialization is generally blocked on its PrefService finishing init which is blocked on its PolicyService being done with init.

On Chrome OS, the Primary profile policies are mirrored into local_state using ProxyPolicyProvider.
Probably due to https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/components/policy/core/common/policy_service_impl.cc?type=cs&sq=package:chromium&g=0&l=188 , at the time primary profile init parts runs (and the primary Profile's PrefService already has policy-set prefs), local_state does not have these yet.

Ensure that primary profile init only coninutes after the policies have been reflected into local_state.

Issue: Commits lost from FreeType mirror.
Issue description:
Reported at https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!topic/chromium-dev/4n2doyhJqk0 . May be related to Issue 978571.

The FreeType mirror at https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/third_party/freetype2/ was set up to mirror upstream FreeType but also allow local branches to be created under /refs/heads/chromium (see https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/admin/repos/chromium/src/third_party/freetype2,access ). Several such branches were created and the commits are referenced by chromium's DEPS in branch-heads 3239, 3440, and 3578. The branches have disappeared so these commits no longer show up in a normal clone. This makes 'gclient sync' on m63, m68, and m71 more or less impossible. I have a local copy with all of these commits from an older checkout. I tried to restore these branches but they were quickly removed again (I assume because they do not exist upstream).

I am assuming this is the result of the combination of the changes in issue 978571 and the use of 'fetch_remove_deleted: true' . I think we can live without 'fetch_remove_deleted: true' with this repo, as that is what I assume was what was happening before. Unfortunately, it is important that these refs be under refs/heads, otherwise we cannot reliably test changes on the trybots (so just forcing these refs into something like /refs/branch-heads/* doesn't really work well).

Issue: @RemovableInRelease ProGuard annotation should use -checkdiscard
Issue description:
It turns out that not everything annotated with @RemovableInRelease is actually being removed in release.

We should make use of -checkdiscard to ensure that the annotation is doing what people think it's doing.

Issue: Official-build time stamps need more precision
Issue description:
Chrome Version: 75.0.3770.142 and 75.0.3770.143
OS: Windows

crrev.com/c/1161104 (and its reland as crrev.com/c/1179281) set the timestamp for official Chrome builds to 5 am UTC on the day of the build. This means that two builds done on the same day will get the same timestamp. Because Windows symbol servers use the timestamp, image size, and filename as the directory-name/index and because the filename and image size change rarely or slowly, this means that we *cannot* do two official builds that are pushed to a symbol server in one day.

This bears repeating: with the current build-system setup we *cannot* do two official builds that are pushed to a symbol server in one day.

If we do then the PE files (chrome.exe, chrome.dll, chrome_child.dll) from the second build will *overwrite* the PE files from the first build. This will make detailed crash analysis impossible (sometimes the incorrect PE file will fail to load) or confusing (because the incorrect PE file does load).

In particular the analysis in https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=964273#c43 went down some misguided paths because the wrong binary was loaded.

Windows developers expect their symbol servers to be 100% accurate and reliable, and Chrome currently does not guarantee this.

To be specific, builds 75.0.3770.142 and 75.0.3770.143 were done within about 4.5 hours of each other and ended up with the same timestamp, image size, and filename for chrome.exe, chrome.dll, and chrome_child.dll, meaning that the .142 binaries were overwritten on the symbol server. This was discovered by Intel when they were analyzing crbug.com/964273

This concern was raised when the CL was originally created:

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1161104/13#message-6faab1f71359ed07ef051df712c890da619c1f26

and the response was "If this CL here does cause any symbol server conflicts, we can and should give lld a mode that does what you suggests."

It's time.

Possible solutions include:
1) Increase the precision of the timestamp, perhaps to one-hour or better. This could optionally only be done on builds that will be published to symbol servers. If this is done for all builds then there is a tradeoff between reproducibility and symbol server reliability and I don't know what the reproducibility benefits are for official builds. If this is only done for builds that are published to symbol servers then we have different behaviors for different official build types.
2) Put a reproducible offset into the time stamp. This could be as simple as adding GUID % 86400 (seconds in a day) or GUID % 3600 (seconds in an hour). This would make the odds of a collision when two builds are done in the same day quite low.
3) Guarantee that we never do two official builds in a day. This seems untenable, especially with canary where do respins fairly frequently.

Issue: [regression] Users not notified that autcomplete is available
Issue description:
Steps:
1. Load data:text/html,<form><label for=in1>Username:</label><input id=in1 type=text name=username required><input type=submit></form>
2. Submit a user name
3. Reload the page
4. Go to chrome://accessibility and view the accessibility tree for the page (you can also check the box to view the internal tree)
5. Note that kAutofillAvailable has not been set on the field

I added some logging and found that WebAXObject::HandleAutofillStateChanged() is called with false instead of true.

This used to work with the old hacky system that had a global static to check whether the autofill menu was visible. That code has now been removed, and therefore users have a degraded experience.

Issue: web_dev_style: add presubmit for .bind(this) in JavaScript
Issue description:
a while ago we added support for arrow function (=>) in chromium.

in that same step to add, we encouraged using () => this.doSomething() over this.doSomething.bind(this).

https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/HEAD/styleguide/web/es.md#arrow-functions

Google JavaScript style guide also encourages => over .bind(this):

https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#features-functions-arrow-functions

I'll add a presubmit that looks for ".bind(this" specifically to start discouraging people from adding more.

It'd be nice to eventually clean up existing .bind(this) usage in chrome (at least in the "webui" parts of the codebase).

Issue: Static DNS servers from policy only apply after reboot
Issue description:
Chrome Version: 79.0.3908.0 (Platform 12494.0.0.19.09.08)
OS: ChromeOS

What steps will reproduce the problem?
(1) Set device ONC policy with static nameservers (e.g. https://paste.googleplex.com/5853168619487232)
(2) Enroll a device
(3) Network settings UI shows the policy values, but they are not used. /etc/resolve.conf also shows the old/default values
(4) After reboot, both UI and /etc/resolv.conf use the values from policy

What is the expected result?
Device should use static nameservers after enrollment


What happens instead?
Device only shows enforced policy values in UI, but doesn't use them until reboot.

Issue: Screen reader can access items with tabindex=-1 that are inside of aria-hidden ancestors.
Issue description:
Chrome Version : 77.0.3865.90
OS Version: OS X 10.14.6
URLs (if applicable) : https://jsbin.com/gegagow/5/edit?html,output
Other browsers tested:
Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
Safari: OK

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Using VoiceOver on the mac, visit https://output.jsbin.com/gegagow
2. Use the VO keys to navigate to the button that says "Inside of aria-hidden".

What is the expected result?
You should not be able to navigate to the control using a screen reader.


What happens instead of that?
You can navigate to the control using a screen reader.

The button has tabindex=-1 and is inside of an ancestor with aria-hidden="true". In Safari you cannot navigate to this control with VoiceOver.


Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.

I think Chrome has changed its behavior here, as previously you could not navigate to these elements. This change breaks the inert polyfill (http://github.com/wicg/inert) which is used in production by a few companies and is relied upon by the Material Components for Web project.

With this change I don't think there's a way to make offscreen content hidden from a screen reader. This technique is useful when you have a large offscreen navigation drawer that you want to be on a compositor layer so you can animate it. If you make the drawer display: none or visibility: hidden it will destroy the compositor layer. This was a primary use case for the inert polyfill.

UserAgentString: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/77.0.3865.90 Safari/537.36

Issue:
SharedWorker's constructor is defined as follows:

constructor(USVString scriptURL, optional (DOMString or WorkerOptions) options = {});

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#shared-workers-and-the-sharedworker-interface

The second argument is a union type, and its default value is {}. When the second argument is omitted, it's expected to create the default WorkerOptions. However, in the current implementation, a null DOMString is created instead.

Issue: Disallow Periodic Background Sync registrations from the background
Issue description:
To prevent developers from coding their websites with the assumption that 'periodic-background-sync' permission will be granted and Periodic Background Sync permitted from an installed web-app, it was decided to disallow registering a Periodic Background Sync request for an origin that doesn't have any top-level frame open.

This is because some browsers might want to show a user prompt for the permission.

Issue: The default value {} for optional DOMStringOrWorkerOptions is misinterpreted
Issue description:
SharedWorker's constructor is defined as follows:

constructor(USVString scriptURL, optional (DOMString or WorkerOptions) options = {});

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#shared-workers-and-the-sharedworker-interface

The second argument is a union type, and its default value is {}. When the second argument is omitted, it's expected to create the default WorkerOptions. However, in the current implementation, a null DOMString is created instead.

Issue: Returned read-only for contenteditable is sometimes wrong
Issue description:
When using Narrator on Windows with UIA, the read-only value returned by the browser for a
that contains a child element is wrong. Consider this example:
Even though the "text field" created from the contenteditable=true div is marked as aria-readonly=false, Narrator announces that the element is read-only. After investigation, I found out that it is caused by the fact that we return the read-only property of the child element of the editable element, the placeholder added on the ::before element. This is expected, but the value should have been inherited from its parent, the editable node.

Issue: Unable to resize extension icons in toolbar after hiding
Issue description:
Chrome Version: 82
OS: All

What steps will reproduce the problem?
(1) Resize extension icons in toolbar to 0.
(2) Resize back to view the icons in the toolbar again.

What is the expected result?
Can do.

What happens instead?
It gets stuck at 0 and won't resize back out anymore. Can't access resize handle anymore.

Performed bisect:
https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/d5b1f92c94fb1b01ebd214597539bda8efd5f8a0..366e9fc958e1a6d8deb578e14c415cc0471293f7

The reproduce tool requires a ClusterFuzz source checkout. To prepare one, run:

git clone https://github.com/google/clusterfuzz && cd clusterfuzz && git checkout tags/reproduce-tool-stable

To reproduce this issue, run:

./reproduce.sh -t https://clusterfuzz.com/testcase-detail/5757326544404480 -b /path/to/build

Please use the GN arguments provided in this report when building the binary. If you have any feedback on reproducing test cases, let us know at https://forms.gle/Yh3qCYFveHj6E5jz5 so we can improve.

Issue: "history.state === popStateEvent.state" depends on evaluation order
getAttribute/hasAttribute on SVG elements causes untimely document lifecycle change
Issue description:
When accessibility is serializing the tree, it gets attributes. During that time, lifecycle changes are not allowed.

A DCHECK protects against this, and the DCHECK is hit when running with accessibility turned on for the following test:

Issue: http/tests/devtools/network/network-initiator.js is flaky
Issue description:
http/tests/devtools/network/network-initiator.js is flaky.

5 flake occurrences of this test have been detected within the
past 24 hours. List of all flake occurrences can be found at:
https://analysis.chromium.org/p/chromium/flake-portal/flakes/occurrences?key=ag9zfmZpbmRpdC1mb3ItbWVyVAsSBUZsYWtlIkljaHJvbWl1bUBibGlua193ZWJfdGVzdHNAaHR0cC90ZXN0cy9kZXZ0b29scy9uZXR3b3JrL25ldHdvcmstaW5pdGlhdG9yLmpzDA.

Unless the culprit CL is found and reverted, please disable this test first
within 30 minutes then find an appropriate owner.

If the result above is wrong, please file a bug using this link:
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/entry?status=Unconfirmed&labels=Pri-1,Test-Flake-Detection-Wrong,Type-Bug&components=Infra%3ETest%3EFlakiness&summary=Flake%20Detection%20-%20Wrong%20result%3A%20http/tests/devtools/network/network-initiator.js&comment=Link%20to%20flake%20details%3A%20https://analysis.chromium.org/p/chromium/flake-portal/flakes/occurrences?key=ag9zfmZpbmRpdC1mb3ItbWVyVAsSBUZsYWtlIkljaHJvbWl1bUBibGlua193ZWJfdGVzdHNAaHR0cC90ZXN0cy9kZXZ0b29scy9uZXR3b3JrL25ldHdvcmstaW5pdGlhdG9yLmpzDA%0A%0AIssue%20Description:%0A%0A

Issue: Variable name |interface| conflicts with |interface| macro in combaseapi.h in Windows SDK
Issue description:
In combaseapi.h, |interface| is defined as "struct". But we have code that uses |interface| as variable name, which could cause compiling errors [1]. I suggest we avoid using |interface| as variable name to avoid this issue, similar to what we've done previously [2].

^

..\..\third_party\depot_tools\win_toolchain\vs_files\9ff60e43ba91947baca460d0ca3b1b980c3a2c23\win_sdk\Include\10.0.18362.0\um\combaseapi.h(168,20): note: expanded from macro '__STRUCT__'

^
..\..\third_party\depot_tools\win_toolchain\vs_files\9ff60e43ba91947baca460d0ca3b1b980c3a2c23\win_sdk\Include\10.0.18362.0\um\combaseapi.h(169,19): note: expanded from macro 'interface'

Issue: WebShare: Consume user activation
Issue description:
NavigatorShare::share should call LocalFrame::ConsumeTransientUserActivation
instead of LocalFrame::HasTransientUserActivation
to consume the user activation.

https://github.com/w3c/web-share/pull/137


A test should call share() twice, with the second call failing with a NotAllowedError. (For example, the test's first call could fail for a reason specified in a later step in the algorithm, e.g. TypeError.)

Issue: ImportantSites: Rename PopulateInfoMapWithInstalled to be more precise.
Issue description:
I will be adding a function to ImportantSitesUtil that populates
an info map with entries for each origin that have an installed
app, so I am renaming this function to represent the fact that
it only populates the map with installed origins that have had
user engagement within the specified time period.

Issue: nasm has known CVEs
Issue description:
These may or may not be important depending on how we use nasm. We don't yet have Vomit set up to report on these, so reporting manually.

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/search/results?form_type=Advanced&cves=on&cpe_version=cpe%3a%2fa%3anasm%3anetwide_assembler%3a2.14%3arc15

nasm is at third_party/nasm and we appear to be using 2.14rc15 plus a selection of changes.

This is presumably solely used as part of our build process (and is security-critical = no) so I am raising as type=Bug not Bug-Security.

Issue: Chromium.shaderc repo is in a broken state (HEAD refers to nonexistent ref)
Issue description:
The repo
https://chromium.googlesource.com/external/github.com/google/shaderc.git
has a HEAD reference that does not refer to any existing branch.

This is generally a symptom of incorrectly handling the removing of a `master` branch. The repo should be updated such that the HEAD reference points to the new `main` branch.

This breaks many git operations with this repo without taking additional manual steps to work around this deficiency:

```
demorri _ ~ _ git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/external/github.com/google/shaderc.git
Cloning into 'shaderc'...
remote: Counting objects: 6, done
remote: Total 6139 (delta 3453), reused 6139 (delta 3453)
Receiving objects: 100% (6139/6139), 2.91 MiB | 16.46 MiB/s, done.
Resolving deltas: 100% (3453/3453), done.
warning: remote HEAD refers to nonexistent ref, unable to checkout.
```

```
demorri _ _ main _ ~/shaderc _ git fetch https://chromium.googlesource.com/external/github.com/google/shaderc.git
fatal: Couldn't find remote ref HEAD
```
